abstract: A U.N. official described Rafah, a refuge for hundreds of thousands of displaced people, as a “pressure cooker of despair.” It is one of the last cities in southern Gaza that Israeli ground forces have not reached.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s defense minister has signaled that ground forces will advance toward the city of Rafah, in the southern Gaza Strip, which has become a refuge for hundreds of thousands of Palestinians pushed from their homes by nearly 13 weeks of war.
headline: Israel Signals Its Military Will Move Into a Gazan City Turned Refuge
keywords: Israel-Gaza War (2023- );Israel;Defense and Military Forces;Gaza Strip;Palestinians;Refugees and Displaced Persons;Rafah (Gaza Strip);Khan Younis (Gaza Strip);Hamas;Terrorism

abstract: Whether dressed in American flag shorts or dirty fatigues, the versatile actor, best known as Apollo Creed in the “Rocky” movies, always made an impression.
lead_paragraph: When you look back on the career of Carl Weathers, who died on Thursday at the age of 76, certain images immediately come to mind. There is Weathers, abs glistening, in American flag shorts in the “Rocky” movies. Or Weathers wearing dirty fatigues in “Predator.” Comedy junkies might immediately picture him waving alongside an alligator in “Happy Gilmore.” Throughout Weathers’s acting career, which followed a stint in professional football, he was associated with franchises that became pop culture sensations. But he was also a performer who was as comfortable goofing on his own persona as he was battling Rocky Balboa or a Predator. Here are some of his most memorable roles and where to watch them.
headline: Watch These Memorable Carl Weathers Performances
keywords: Weathers, Carl;Actors and Actresses;Movies;Television;Rocky (Movie);Happy Gilmore (Movie);Predator (Movie);Toy Story 4 (Movie);The Mandalorian (TV Program);ARRESTED DEVELOPMENT (TV PROGRAM)

abstract: He was half of the twin-guitar attack that drove the influential Detroit band’s  live performances and  helped set the stage for punk rock.
lead_paragraph: Wayne Kramer, a founder and guitarist of the incendiary Detroit band the MC5, whose furious musical salvos against all things Establishment made them a house band of sorts for the radical left in the late 1960s and early ’70s and helped set the template for punk rock, died on Friday in Los Angeles. He was 75.
headline: Wayne Kramer, Guitarist With the Incendiary MC5, Is Dead at 75
keywords: Kramer, Wayne (1948-2024);Deaths (Obituaries);Pop and Rock Music;MC5

abstract: But it is a sparkling debut by Carolyn Davies Lynch, in collaboration with Jeff Chen.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Today we have a first-time constructor, Carolyn Davies Lynch, who is living the dream: She’s a happy solver who took one little step in the perfect direction, toward Jeff Chen. A co-founder of xwordinfo.com, Mr. Chen has helped dozens of newbies get started in the puzzleverse; he has now made 151 puzzles for The New York Times, 58 of which have at least one collaborator alongside him. (Give his new invention a try when you’re done here; it’s light and bright but also challenging!)
headline: What It’s Not, in a Saying

abstract: The federal financial aid formula used to give a break to families with two or more children in college at a time. That’s gone now, and some schools may not fill the gap.

headline: Will Families Pay Less With Two Students in College? Now, It Depends.

abstract: In Rebecca K Reilly’s book, “Greta & Valdin,” two 20-something siblings navigate love, identity and growing up while wading through the maelstrom of contemporary life.
lead_paragraph: Labels and tropes have always been a part of the book world, but recently it feels like they’ve gained new prominence. Tags like “enemies to lovers,” “morally gray heroes,” “found family narrative,” etc., are everywhere now, especially online. Neatly classifying books has become all the rage. “Greta & Valdin,” Rebecca K Reilly’s generous, tender debut novel of family and self-acceptance, however, is not so easily pigeonholed.
headline: A Debut Novel About the Beautiful Chaos of Modern Young Adulthood
keywords: Books and Literature;Greta & Valdin (Book);Reilly, Rebecca K (Author)

abstract: As libraries become battlegrounds in the nation’s culture wars, their allies are fighting to preserve access to their collections and keep themselves out of jail, or worse.
lead_paragraph: During 12 years as a youth librarian in northern Idaho, Denise Neujahr read to and befriended children of many backgrounds. Devout or atheist, gay or straight, all were welcome until a November evening in 2021, when about two dozen teens arriving at the Post Falls library for a meeting of the “Rainbow Squad” encountered a commotion at the entrance.
headline: Cast as Criminals, America’s Librarians Rally to Their Own Defense

abstract: Pushed by an advocacy group, Arkansas became the first state to shield noisy cryptocurrency operators from unhappy neighbors. A furious backlash has some lawmakers considering a statewide ban.
lead_paragraph: On a sweltering July evening, the din from thousands of computers mining for Bitcoins pierced the night. Nearby, Matt Brown, a member of the Arkansas legislature, monitored the noise alongside a local magistrate.
headline: Anxiety, Mood Swings and Sleepless Nights: Life Near a Bitcoin Mine
keywords: Arkansas;Bitcoin (Currency);Data Centers;Noise;Pollution;Environment;Law and Legislation;State Legislatures;United States Politics and Government;Suits and Litigation (Civil);Blockchain (Technology);Virtual Currency;Regulation and Deregulation of Industry;Computers and the Internet;internal-truncator

abstract: There are several avenues you can take to try to get better leadership. Whichever you choose, make sure it stands up to legal scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: Q: My luxury condo building in Manhattan has fallen into disrepair, and the board of managers is thwarting efforts to improve it. Over the past 10 years, we’ve been unable to reach a quorum for the annual meeting, which has prevented any new candidates from joining the board or voting for any real changes. The board declares there’s a lack of quorum, but attendance is not taken. The president has been there since the board began, more than 35 years ago. Mandatory work is awarded to questionable contractors, and there have been rumors of impropriety. For example, the board distributed a memo announcing a $100 penalty for each piece of correspondence distributed within the building, such as fliers in public areas or under doors. Owners’ efforts to organize have been rebuffed. What can we do?
headline: The Condo Board Is Ruining Our Building! How Do We Get Them Out?
keywords: Real Estate and Housing (Residential);Condominiums;Boards of Directors

abstract: Paul Pfeiffer’s transcendent manipulations of broadcast footage are intimate confrontations with spectacles meant for millions.
lead_paragraph: What would a basketball game be like without the ebb and flow of two teams, without the roar of the crowd? Like Paul Pfeiffer’s videos. The multimedia artist, whose first career survey in the United States is on view at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles (MOCA) through June 16, began with a suite of videos in which the whole seething, popping commotion has been removed from found live footage, leaving the central monumental figure of an athlete.
headline: Frame by Frame, an Artist Distills What Sports Cameras Blur
keywords: Art;Pfeiffer, Paul;Content Type: Personal Profile;Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art;Athletics and Sports

abstract: The movie, with its handful of Oscar nominations, has refocused attention on “Erasure,” a satire of the literary world and its racial biases.
lead_paragraph: There’s a scene in Percival Everett’s 2001 novel, “Erasure,” in which the main character, a cerebral Black novelist named Thelonious “Monk” Ellison, goes to a bookstore to hunt, as writers often do, for his own books. He finds four of them — including “The Persians,” an “obscure reworking of a Greek tragedy” — placed, infuriatingly, in the “African American Studies” section.
headline: The Book Behind ‘American Fiction’ Came Out 23 Years Ago. It’s Still Current.

abstract: While a grand trip might offer novelty and excitement, there’s adventure to be found in territories much closer to home.

abstract: Lawyers for the failed crypto exchange told a bankruptcy judge they expected to pay creditors in full.
lead_paragraph: When the cryptocurrency exchange FTX declared bankruptcy about 15 months ago, it seemed few customers would recover much money or crypto from the platform. As John Ray III, who took over as chief executive during the bankruptcy, put it, “At the end of the day, we’re not going to be able to recover all the losses here.” He was countering Sam Bankman-Fried’s repeated claims that he could get every customer their money back.
headline: What Happens to FTX Clawback Cases if the Company Repays Its Creditors?

abstract: Surviving members of the all-Black Tennessee A&I basketball team have fought for recognition since they won three back-to-back national championships at the height of the Jim Crow era.

abstract: The idea of a first minister who supports closer ties to the Republic of Ireland — let alone one from Sinn Fein, a party with historic ties to the Irish Republican Army — was once unthinkable. On Saturday, it became reality.

abstract: Plan for an early night — polls close at 7 p.m. Eastern, and the results will most likely be available not long after.
lead_paragraph: Expect a relatively early night Saturday in South Carolina, where President Biden faces scant opposition in the first official Democratic primary of the cycle. abstract: “Awesome recipe. Works well. Always impresses.”
lead_paragraph: We here at New York Times Cooking love a good cry, whether we’re attending a wedding, watching that one episode of “The Last of Us” or chopping three pounds of onions for French onion soup. As Sara Bonisteel notes in her recipe, which has five stars and over 5,000 reviews, you’ll spend a good bit of time caramelizing all those onions, but it’s always worth the wait (and tears). A deeply flavored, savory-sweet bowl of sable-brown French onion soup on a cold winter weekend? With thick slabs of toast blanketed in melted cheese? We’re misting up a little just thinking about it.
headline: Our Five-Star French Onion Soup Is Worth the Tears
keywords: Cooking and Cookbooks;Content Type: Service
